Sarah_Jarosz:
{{short description|American musician}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2018}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Sarah Jarosz | image = Sarah Jarosz Big Barn - Purbeck VFF 2023 (53141875202).jpg | caption = Jarosz at the Purbeck Valley Folk Festival in 2023 | image_size = 250px | birth_name = Sarah Ellen Jarosz | alias = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1991|5|23|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Austin, Texas]], U.S. | instrument = {{hlist|Vocals|[[mandolin]]|[[banjo]]|guitar|[[octave mandolin]]}} | genre = {{hlist|[[Americana (music)|Americana]]|[[country folk]]|[[Progressive bluegrass|bluegrass]]|[[Folk music|folk]]}} | occupation = Singer-songwriter | years_active = 2009–present | label = {{hlist|[[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill]]|[[Rounder Records|Rounder]]}} | current_member_of = [[I'm with Her (band)|I'm with Her]] | website = {{URL|sarahjarosz.com}} }} '''Sarah Ellen Jarosz''' ({{IPAc-en|dʒ|ə|ˈ|r|oʊ|z}} {{respell|jə|ROHZ|'}}; born May 23, 1991) is an American singer-songwriter from [[Wimberley, Texas]]. Her debut studio album, ''[[Song Up in Her Head]]'', was released in 2009[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=105374610 "A Bluegrass Debutante, A High School Graduate"] ''NPR All Songs Considered''. June 14, 2009. Retrieved January 21, 2010. and the song "Mansinneedof" was nominated for a [[Grammy Awards|Grammy Award]] in the category of [[Grammy Award for Best Country Instrumental Performance|Best Country Instrumental Performance]].[http://www.grammy.com/grammy_awards/52nd_show/list.aspx#08 "52nd Annual Grammy Awards Nominees List"] ''Grammys''. Retrieved January 21, 2010. Her second studio album, ''[[Follow Me Down (album)|Follow Me Down]]'', released in 2011, received a Song of the Year nomination from the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Music Association's 2012 Honors and Awards]]. Her third studio album, ''[[Build Me Up from Bones]]'', was released on September 24, 2013 through [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]]. ''[[Build Me Up from Bones]]'' was nominated for [[Grammy Award for Best Folk Album|Best Folk Album]] at the [[56th Annual Grammy Awards]], and its title track was nominated for Best American Roots Song.{{cite web|url=http://www.grammy.com/nominees|title=GRAMMY.com - The Official Site of Music's Biggest Night|work=The GRAMMYs|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} In 2016, Jarosz released her fourth studio album, ''[[Undercurrent (Sarah Jarosz album)|Undercurrent]]''. The album won two Grammy Awards (Best Folk Album and [[Grammy Award for Best American Roots Performance|Best American Roots Performance]] for the song "House of Mercy"). On June 5, 2020 she released the album ''[[World on the Ground]]'', her first solo studio album in four years. It was nominated for two Grammy Awards (Best American Roots Song and Best Americana Album) with Jarosz winning in the [[Grammy Award for Best Americana Album|Best Americana Album]] category. ==Early life and education== Sarah Ellen Jarosz{{cite web|url=https://www.ascap.com/repertory#/ace/search/workID/903658223 |title=ANNABELLE LEE |website=ASCAP |publisher=American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers |access-date=April 26, 2023}} was born in [[Austin, Texas]],{{cite web |title=Sarah Jarosz Build Me Up From Bones |url=https://www.austinchronicle.com/music/2013-10-04/sarah-jarosz-build-me-up-from-bones/ |publisher=[[Austin Chronicle]] |accessdate=June 15, 2018 |date=October 4, 2013}} and raised in [[Wimberley, Texas]]. Her parents were teachers. Her last name is [[Polish people|Polish]].{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/daniel-menaker/all-that-jarosz_b_865977.html|title=All That Jarosz|work=The Huffington Post|date=May 24, 2011 |accessdate=August 5, 2015}} She began learning the [[mandolin]] at age 10 and later began learning to play the guitar, clawhammer banjo, and octave mandolin. During her senior year of high school, Jarosz signed a recording contract with [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]] and released her debut album ''[[Song Up in Her Head]]'' in June 2009; it was produced by Jarosz and [[Gary Paczosa]]. Guest musicians on the album included [[Chris Thile]], [[Darrell Scott]], [[Stuart Duncan]], and [[Jerry Douglas]]. Jarosz enrolled in the [[New England Conservatory of Music]] in 2009, and graduated with honors in 2013 with a degree in Contemporary Improvisation. ==Career== [[File:Sarah Jarosz 2014.jpg|thumb|200px|right|Jarosz performing in [[San Francisco]], 2014]] In 2010 Jarosz recorded the album ''Follow Me Down'' and again shared production duties with [[Gary Paczosa]]. The album was recorded in Nashville and features guest musicians [[Bela Fleck]], Jerry Douglas, Stuart Duncan, [[Viktor Krauss]], [[Dan Tyminski]], [[Shawn Colvin]], Darrell Scott, and bandmates Alex Hargreaves and Nathaniel Smith. A session with [[Punch Brothers]] in New York produced a cover of the [[Radiohead]] song "The Tourist". An ''American Songwriter'' reviewer wrote that "Jarosz invites us along with her into a growing sonic space of collaboration and artistry at this the second step in what will surely be a long and productive musical journey." In 2011 Jarosz performed at [[Jerry Douglas]]' the [[Transatlantic Sessions]] in Scotland. She performed [[Bob Dylan]]'s "Ring Them Bells."{{cite web|url=http://ernesttroost.com/blog/sarah_jarosz__the_transatlantic_sessions/|title=Ernest Troost|work=ernesttroost.com|accessdate=August 5, 2015}} In 2012, Jarosz appeared on [[Kate Rusby]]'s album ''[[20 (Kate Rusby album)|20]]'', collaborating with Rusby on the song "Planets". In 2015, Jarosz toured extensively with [[Sara Watkins]] (a founding member of [[Nickel Creek]]) and [[Aoife O'Donovan]] (of [[Crooked Still]] fame) as well as going on tour with [[Garrison Keillor]] on ''The America the Beautiful Tour – A Prairie Home Companion''.{{cite web | url=http://www.folkradio.co.uk/2015/04/im-with-her-tour-sara-watkins-sarah-jarosz-and-aoife-odonovan/ | title=I'm with Her Tour: Sara Watkins, Sarah Jarosz and Aoife O'Donovan | work=Folk Radio UK | date=April 26, 2015 | accessdate=April 23, 2016}}{{cite web | url=http://prairiehome.org/america-the-beautiful/ | title=The America the Beautiful Tour | work=A Prairie Home Companion | accessdate=April 23, 2016}} In 2016, she became a regular performer on the weekly [[NPR]] series ''[[Live from Here]]'', hosted by [[Chris Thile]].{{cite web | url=https://www.livefromhere.org/pages/performers-staff-writers/ | title=Live from Here with Chris Thile: Performers and Staff | work=[[National Public Radio|NPR]] | accessdate=June 24, 2020}} Together with Watkins and O'Donovan, Jarosz became a founding member of the progressive-folk trio [[I'm With Her (band)|I'm With Her]]. They released their debut album, ''[[See You Around]]'', in 2018. Her fourth studio album, ''Undercurrent'', was released on June 17, 2016.{{cite web | url=http://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2016/03/sarah-jarosz-announces-her-fourth-album-undercurre.html | title=Sarah Jarosz Announces Her Fourth Album Undercurrent For June Release | work=Paste Magazine | date=March 1, 2016 | accessdate=April 23, 2016}} It won the Grammy for [[Best Folk Album]] along with the song "House of Mercy" winning the Grammy for [[Best American Roots Performance]] at the [[59th Annual Grammy Awards|2017 Grammy Awards]].{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7597556/grammys-nominees-complete-list-2017|title=Here Is the Complete List of Nominees for the 2017 Grammys|magazine=Billboard|accessdate=September 15, 2019}}{{Cite web |url=https://www.grammy.com/nominees/search?artist=%22Sarah+Jarosz%22&field_nominee_work_value=&year=All&genre=All |title=Past winners search |website=grammy.org}} In 2020, Jarosz returned to her solo career with her fifth studio album, ''[[World on the Ground]]''.{{cite web |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Sarah Jarosz Previews New Album 'World on the Ground' With Wistful Song 'Johnny' |url=https://www.msn.com/en-us/music/news/sarah-jarosz-previews-new-album-world-on-the-ground-with-wistful-song-johnny/ar-BB11DWbv |publisher=MSN |accessdate=7 April 2020}} This was followed 11 months later by the release of her sixth studio album, ''[[Blue Heron Suite]]''. The previously-shelved collection was originally written and recorded between 2017 and 2018.{{cite web |last1=Farthing |first1=Lydia |title=Sarah Jarosz To Release New Project, 'Blue Heron Suite' |url=https://musicrow.com/2021/04/sarah-jarosz-to-release-new-project-blue-heron-suite/ |website=Music Row |date=April 14, 2021 |publisher=Music Row Enterprises, LLC |access-date=25 June 2021}} On September 7, 2023, Jarosz released the official video of her song "Jealous Moon", from her album ''[[Polaroid Lovers]]'', which was released on January 26, 2024.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=w8SuGm1aD-A |title=Sarah Jarosz: Jealous Moon (Official video) |last=Jarosz |first=Sarah |date=September 7, 2023 |website=[[YouTube]]|access-date=September 8, 2023}} October 10 saw the release of "Columbus & 89th", the second single off the album.{{Cite web|url=https://femmusic.com/wp/2023/10/10/sarah-jarosz-columbus-89th/|title=Sarah Jarosz – Columbus & 89th|author=FEM MUSIC Staff|date=October 10, 2023|publisher=FEMMUSIC.com|accessdate=October 15, 2023}} ==Critical reception== Jarosz has been called "a songwriter of uncommon wisdom" by the ''[[Austin Chronicle]]''.Moser, Margaret. [http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/review?oid=oid%3A792554 "Texas Platters: Sarah Jarosz"] ''[[Austin Chronicle]]''. June 12, 2009. Retrieved January 21, 2010. Jarosz has been interviewed by [[NPR]] and ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and described as a contemporary-bluegrass [[Child prodigy|prodigy]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=105374610|title=A Bluegrass Débutante, A Highschool Graduate|work=[[All Things Considered]]|date=June 13, 2009|publisher=[[NPR]]|accessdate=December 3, 2014}} A ''[[New York Times]]'' reviewer wrote that Jarosz is "widely regarded as one of acoustic music's most promising young talents: a singer-songwriter and mandolin and banjo prodigy with the taste and poise to strike that rare balance of commercial and critical success."{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/08/us/08ttlanger.htm0l|title=Singer, Songwriter, Prodigy, All at 19"|last=Langer|first=Andy|date=May 7, 2011|work=[[The Texas Tribune]]|publisher=[[New York Times]]|accessdate=December 3, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230908190303/https://www.nytimes.com/2011/05/08/us/08ttlanger.html|archive-date=September 8, 2023}} Her 2013 release, ''[[Build Me Up from Bones]]'', was dubbed by Stereo Subversion as an "organic masterwork...a warm, nuanced collection that wraps and enchants the listener", as well as "her boldest work yet" by WNYC Soundcheck.
